newsitem.title: CHINA: Chinese-ruled HK struggles to define law and order.
newsitem.headline: Chinese-ruled HK struggles to define law and order.

text.p: Hong Kong police, barristers and judges are scrambling to define what law and order mean now the territory is under new management.
British colonial rule ended at midnight on June 30 when Hong Kong reverted to China.
Although the territory's unique way of life is guaranteed for 50 years under a treaty between London and Beijing, certain institutions, laws and customs no longer prevail.
Sorting out what the changes mean practically could be a long process as Hong Kong's post-handover legal and political systems strive for an accommodation.
Hong Kong, long known as a bastion of civil liberties in Asia, now has a new Public Order Ordinance which allows police to ban public processions deemed to threaten national security.
Human and political rights activists fear freedom of speech and assembly could be seriously curtailed.

Police chief Eddie Hui on Thursday directed that national security -- defined as "safeguarding the territorial integrity and the independence of the People's Republic of China" -- could not be invoked by anyone below his Director of Operations.
Jean Chan, a police spokeswoman, went further on Friday by stating that "my understanding is that the issue of national security is not for us (the police) to decide".
Left unclear is who will determine when China's national security is threatened, and on what basis.
It could be Hong Kong's new Chief Executive, Tung Chee-hwa, or the Provisional Legislature which revised the Public Order Ordinance.
Appointed by Beijing to replace Hong Kong's elected Legislative Council, the Provisional Legislature's legal authority to pass laws is itself questioned by leading barristers.

Even proper terms of address were in doubt in Hong Kong courts on Thursday when one judge acknowledged not knowing whether he should still be spoken to as "Your Lordship" -- a title not much in favour in communist-ruled China.

Reports that Hong Kong police were liaising with Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) troops garrisoned in the territory caused a frisson of excitement, too, among some who fear the soldiers might be used to quell civil disorder.
But the police said on Friday there was still no formal contact between the PLA, who replaced British troops at midnight on June 30 and the Hong Kong police.

"There won't be any problem contacting the PLA should the need arise but the liaison is yet to be set up," said spokeswoman Chan. "We are talking to them but we haven't formalised any sort of arrangement yet."
